questions.text: Twelve hours after admission to the hospital because of a high-grade fever for 3 days, a 15-year-old boy has shortness of breath. During this period, he has had generalized malaise and a cough productive of moderate amounts of green sputum. For the past 10 days, he has had fever, a sore throat, and muscle aches; these symptoms initially improved, but worsened again over the past 5 days. His temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F), pulse is 109/min, respirations are 27/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 93%. There are decreased breath sounds and crackles heard over the right upper lung field. His hemoglobin concentration is 13.3 g/dL, leukocyte count is 15,000/mm3, and platelet count is 289,000/mm3. An x-ray of the chest shows a right upper-lobe infiltrate. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Klebsiella species are a common cause of hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP), and community-acquired pneumonia in patients with alcohol use disorder. HAP can only be diagnosed if pneumonia develops > 48 hours after the patient is admitted to the hospital. Klebsiella species cause pneumonia that is classically associated with currant jelly sputum and Klebsiella species are not a common cause of postviral bacterial pneumonia.

B) CORRECT:

The most common causes of postviral bacterial pneumonia are Streptococcus pneumoniae, Staphylococcus aureus, and Haemophilus influenzae. Bacterial superinfection should be suspected in any patient presenting with exacerbation of fever and severe respiratory symptoms after initial improvement of flu symptoms. The influenza virus causes a dysfunction of the tracheobronchial epithelium, which makes affected patients more susceptible to secondary infection with bacteria. Post-influenza pneumonia should be treated empirically with antibiotics until culture results are available.

C) INCORRECT:

Mycoplasma pneumoniae is a common cause of atypical pneumonia. In contrast with this patient's findings, atypical pneumonia typically manifests with a dry rather than a productive cough and has an indolent course; pulmonary auscultation is often unremarkable. Mycoplasma pneumoniae is also not a common cause of postviral bacterial pneumonia.

D) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus epidermidis is responsible for device-related infections, which can occur in patients with intravenous catheters, heart valves, or orthopedic implants. S. epidermidis is not a common cause of bacterial pneumonia. A different Staphylococcus species is a common cause of postviral bacterial pneumonia.

E) INCORRECT:

Chlamydophila pneumoniae is a common cause of atypical pneumonia. In contrast with this patient's findings, atypical pneumonia typically manifests with a dry rather than a productive cough and has an indolent course; pulmonary auscultation is often unremarkable. Chlamydophila pneumoniae is also not a common cause of postviral bacterial pneumonia.

F) INCORRECT:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a common cause of hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP), and community-acquired pneumonia in patients with underlying chronic lung disease (e.g., COPD, bronchiectasis). This patient does not have chronic lung disease and HAP can only be diagnosed if pneumonia develops > 48 hours after the patient is admitted to the hospital. P. aeruginosa is not a common cause of postviral bacterial pneumonia.

G) INCORRECT:

Legionella pneumophila can cause pneumonia but also typically manifests with gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., nausea, vomiting, diarrhea) and neurological features (e.g., altered mental status), which are not seen here. Moreover, L. pneumophila is not a common cause of postviral bacterial pneumonia. L. pneumophila infection is contracted by inhaling contaminated aerosols, which can happen in confined spaces like cruise ships, hotels, resorts, or nursing homes.
questions.hint: This patient initially had features of influenza (malaise, fever, sore throat, muscle ache) and now presents with features of bacterial pneumonia (productive cough, infiltrate on chest x-ray). Postviral bacterial pneumonia is often caused by specific pathogens.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old boy is brought to the Emergency Department with a 2-day history of fever, productive cough, and increased fussiness. He has received all recommended childhood immunizations. Examination shows crackles over the right lower lung field and mild intercostal retractions (see report).

Temperature
38.5°C

Chest radiograph: Right lower lobe consolidation
Which organism is the most likely cause of this patient’s pneumonia?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) was a common cause of pediatric pneumonia before the Hib vaccine. The widespread immunization has significantly reduced its incidence. This fully immunized child is unlikely to have Hib pneumonia, which typically occurred in unvaccinated children and presented more severely.

B) INCORRECT:

Mycoplasma pneumoniae is associated with atypical pneumonia, usually in older children and young adults. It presents with a gradual onset, dry cough, and interstitial infiltrates, unlike the focal lobar consolidation and productive cough seen in this 3-year-old. The presentation is more consistent with typical bacterial pneumonia.

C) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus pneumonia often follows a viral infection, such as influenza, and presents with severe, rapidly progressive symptoms. It typically causes multifocal or patchy infiltrates, not a single lobar consolidation. The absence of a preceding viral illness and the localized right lower lobe consolidation make S. aureus less likely in this 3-year-old with a brief symptom history.

D) CORRECT:

Streptococcus pneumoniae, a Gram-positive encapsulated diplococcus, is the leading cause of community-acquired pneumonia in children. It often causes lobar pneumonia, as indicated by the right lower lobe consolidation on the chest radiograph and the presence of crackles and intercostal retractions. Despite vaccination, S. pneumoniae remains prevalent due to multiple serotypes not covered by the vaccine. Its virulence is primarily due to its polysaccharide capsule, which evades the host immune response, leading to inflammation and alveolar consolidation. The clinical presentation of fever and productive cough aligns with typical bacterial pneumonia caused by S. pneumoniae.

Key learning point: In young children, Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common cause of bacterial pneumonia, especially in those who are up to date with vaccinations.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with a 3-day history of fever, cough, and decreased oral intake. The child is alert but appears tired. Vital signs are T, 38.8°C (102.0°F); P, 125; R, 42; oxygen saturation, 91% on room air. Physical examination reveals fine crackles in the left lower lobe. Laboratory results show a WBC count of 15,000/μL. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Respiratory viral panel and discharge if negative

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although a respiratory viral panel is indicated for children with suspected pneumonia, discharge is inappropriate for a patient with hypoxemia regardless of the viral panel results.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient's acute presentation with focal findings and elevated WBC count suggests typical bacterial pneumonia rather than atypical pneumonia. Additionally, outpatient oral therapy is inappropriate for a patient with hypoxemia.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- Hypoxemia (this patient's oxygen saturation is 91%, which is below the 90% threshold) meets the criteria for hospital admission, which is required for intravenous antibiotics and close monitoring. This patient's fever, focal findings, and elevated WBC count suggest bacterial pneumonia requiring intravenous therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Outpatient management is inappropriate for a patient with hypoxemia (oxygen saturation of 91%).

E) INCORRECT:

Although a chest x-ray may be obtained, it should not delay treatment. This patient's clinical presentation and hypoxemia warrant immediate management.

questions.text: A 4-year-old previously healthy child presents with a 3-day history of fever, productive cough, and decreased oral intake. The child appears lethargic. Vital signs are T, 39.1°C (102.4°F); P, 138; R, 36; oxygen saturation, 89% on room air. Physical examination shows decreased breath sounds and crackles in the right lower lobe. After initiating supplemental oxygen, what is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Start oral amoxicillin and arrange outpatient follow-up in 48 hours
Administer intravenous ampicillin and prepare for admission
Start intravenous azithromycin for atypical pneumonia coverage
Obtain chest x-ray and complete blood count before further treatment
Obtain respiratory viral panel and blood cultures before starting antibiotics

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral antibiotics and outpatient management do not provide adequate monitoring or treatment intensity for this patient's clinical severity.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous antibiotics and admission are appropriate; however, initiating treatment before collecting key diagnostic studies may limit the ability to tailor therapy optimally.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient's clinical presentation with productive cough, fever, and lobar findings is more consistent with typical bacterial pneumonia requiring beta-lactam coverage.

D) INCORRECT:

While imaging and blood tests are useful, prioritizing other diagnostic studies can better inform early antibiotic selection and management decisions.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- This child's hypoxemia and signs of respiratory distress warrant admission. After oxygen support, the next step is obtaining appropriate diagnostic studies, including respiratory viral panel and blood cultures, before initiating antibiotic therapy.
